liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Jordan says it is leaving "all options" open in its response to what it called Israel's failure to discriminate between military and civilian targets in its intensifying bombardment and invasion of the Gaza Strip. Prime Minister Bisher al Khasawneh said "all options are on the table for Jordan in our dealing with the Israeli aggression on Gaza and its repercussions," but did not elaborate on what steps the kingdom would take. Last week Jordan recalled its ambassador and announced that Israel's ambassador, who left Amman shortly after Hamas' attack, would not be allowed to come back, effectively declaring him persona non grata. Mr Khasawneh said Israel's siege of the densely populated Gaza was not self-defence as it maintains. "The brutal Israeli attack does not discriminate between civilian and military targets and is extending to safe areas and ambulances," he said. In a statement, Israel's foreign ministry said the country's "relations with Jordan are of strategic importance to both countries and we regret the inflammatory statements from Jordan's leadership". Yesterday, Jordan's King Abdullah II said his air force dropped "urgent medical aid" to a field hospital operated by the kingdom in Gaza. The airdrop bypasses a growing bottleneck of aid deliveries to Gaza via Rafah, the enclave's border crossing with Egypt. The Jordanian army have operated the 40-bed hospital, on the outskirts of Gaza City, since 2009. Israel says it "coordinated" with Jordan on the drop and that the aid "will be used by the medical staff for patients," and also includes food. The Israel-Gaza war is tricky for Jordan to navigate. The nation is a unique player in the region, walking a diplomatic tightrope as it seeks to maintain ties with neighbours and powerful allies. The conflict also appears to be putting pressure on the kingdom's rulers, King Abdullah and Queen Rania. My colleague Lucia Stein and I wrote a story about it, which you can read below if you'd like to learn more.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordan open to 'all options' as Gaza conflict intensifies

featuredLink.title: Why an 'extraordinary' statement by Queen Rania was the first sign of shifting priorities in Jordan

children.content: Jordan says it is leaving "all options" open in its response to what it called Israel's failure to discriminate between military and civilian targets in its intensifying bombardment and invasion of the Gaza Strip.

Prime Minister Bisher al Khasawneh said "all options are on the table for Jordan in our dealing with the Israeli aggression on Gaza and its repercussions," but did not elaborate on what steps the kingdom would take.

Last week Jordan recalled its ambassador and announced that Israel's ambassador, who left Amman shortly after Hamas' attack, would not be allowed to come back, effectively declaring him persona non grata.
Mr Khasawneh said Israel's siege of the densely populated Gaza was not self-defence as it maintains.
"The brutal Israeli attack does not discriminate between civilian and military targets and is extending to safe areas and ambulances," he said.
In a statement, Israel's foreign ministry said the country's "relations with Jordan are of strategic importance to both countries and we regret the inflammatory statements from Jordan's leadership".
Yesterday, Jordan's King Abdullah II said his air force dropped "urgent medical aid" to a field hospital operated by the kingdom in Gaza.
The airdrop bypasses a growing bottleneck of aid deliveries to Gaza via Rafah, the enclave's border crossing with Egypt.
The Jordanian army have operated the 40-bed hospital, on the outskirts of Gaza City, since 2009.
Israel says it "coordinated" with Jordan on the drop and that the aid "will be used by the medical staff for patients," and also includes food.
The Israel-Gaza war is tricky for Jordan to navigate. The nation is a unique player in the region, walking a diplomatic tightrope as it seeks to maintain ties with neighbours and powerful allies.
The conflict also appears to be putting pressure on the kingdom's rulers, King Abdullah and Queen Rania.
My colleague Lucia Stein and I wrote a story about it, which you can read below
if you'd like to learn more.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The operator of the Indonesia hospital in Gaza has denied accusations that its facility has been used by Hamas to launch attacks. The comments were in response to the Israeli military's repeated accusation that Hamas uses hospitals, including Gaza's main hospital al-Shifa, the Qatari-funded Sheikh Hamad Hospital and a hospital built by groups from Indonesia, as cover to shield its underground operations. "We built this hospital to help others, according to the needs of the Gazans," said Sarbini Abdul Murad, the chairman of MER-C, a voluntary group operating the Indonesia hospital. "Israel's accusation is a precondition so that they can attack the Indonesian hospital in Gaza," he told a press conference in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta. Israel's military spokesperson on Sunday claimed one satellite image had shown rocket launchers located across the street from the Indonesian hospital. Another official at MER-C said there was no tunnels under the hospital and that its fuel tank and power generators are kept in separate nearby buildings for security reasons. Indonesia, the world's biggest Muslim-majority country, has called for an immediate ceasefire and has sent humanitarian aid to Gaza. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Indonesia group denies hospital used by Hamas network

children.content: The operator of the Indonesia hospital in Gaza has denied accusations that its facility has been used by Hamas to launch attacks.

The comments were in response to the Israeli military's repeated accusation that Hamas uses hospitals, including Gaza's main hospital al-Shifa, the Qatari-funded Sheikh Hamad Hospital and a hospital built by groups from Indonesia, as cover to shield its underground operations.
"We built this hospital to help others, according to the needs of the Gazans," said Sarbini Abdul Murad, the chairman of MER-C, a voluntary group operating the Indonesia hospital.
"Israel's accusation is a precondition so that they can attack the Indonesian hospital in Gaza," he told a press conference in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta.
Israel's military spokesperson on Sunday claimed one satellite image had shown rocket launchers located across the street from the Indonesian hospital.
Another official at MER-C said there was no tunnels under the hospital and that its fuel tank and power generators are kept in separate nearby buildings for security reasons.
Indonesia, the world's biggest Muslim-majority country, has called for an immediate ceasefire and has sent humanitarian aid to Gaza.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today marks one month since Hamas attacked southern Israel, killing more than 1,400 people and taking some 240 hostage, sparking the current conflict. Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn reports from the square opposite the IDF headquarters in central Tel Aviv which has been transformed into a "living reminder" of the hostages.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel marks one month since October 7 attacks

children.content: Today marks one month since Hamas attacked southern Israel, killing more than 1,400 people and taking some 240 hostage, sparking the current conflict.
Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn reports from the square opposite the IDF headquarters in central Tel Aviv which has been transformed into a "living reminder" of the hostages.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We won't know for sure what the RBA will do with interest rates until 2:30pm AEDT, but all of the big four banks are united in their thinking. Here's what they're predicting the RBA to do this afternoon: ANZ: 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35% Westpac: 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35% NAB: 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35% Commonwealth Bank: 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35% (For what it's worth, money markets have priced in a roughly 70% chance of a rate increase today.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: This is what the big four banks think the RBA will do with interest rates this afternoon

children.content: We won't know for sure what the RBA will do with interest rates until
2:30pm AEDT
, but all of the big four banks are united in their thinking.
Here's what they're predicting the RBA to do this afternoon:
ANZ:
0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35%
Westpac:
0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35%
NAB:
0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35%
Commonwealth Bank:
0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35%
(For what it's worth, money markets have priced in a roughly 70% chance of a rate increase today.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oil prices edged higher on Monday after top exporters Saudi Arabia and Russia reaffirmed their commitment to extra voluntary oil supply cuts until the end of the year. Brent crude futures rose 0.3% to $US85.18 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 0.4% to $US80.82. Saudi Arabia confirmed on Sunday it would continue its additional voluntary cut of 1 million barrels per day (bpd) in December to keep output around 9 million bpd, a ministry of energy source said. Russia also announced it would continue its additional voluntary cut of 300,000 bpd from its crude oil and petroleum product exports until the end of December. The cuts could be extended into the first quarter of 2024 because of "seasonally weaker oil demand at the start of every year, ongoing economic growth concerns and the aim of producers and OPEC+ to support the oil market's stability and balance", said UBS strategist Giovanni Staunovo. Oil prices rebounded after both benchmarks fell by around 6% in the week to November 3, as supply concerns driven by Middle East tensions eased. UN agency leaders demanded a humanitarian ceasefire on Monday, a month into the war in Gaza, as health authorities in the enclave said the death toll from Israeli strikes now exceeded 10,000.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Oil prices rise as Saudi Arabia and Russia stick to supply cuts

children.content: Oil prices edged higher on Monday after top exporters Saudi Arabia and Russia reaffirmed their commitment to extra voluntary oil supply cuts until the end of the year.
Brent crude futures
rose 0.3% to $US85.18 a barrel, while
US West Texas Intermediate crude
gained 0.4% to $US80.82.
Saudi Arabia confirmed on Sunday it would continue its additional voluntary cut of 1 million barrels per day (bpd) in December to keep output around 9 million bpd, a ministry of energy source said.
Russia also announced it would continue its additional voluntary cut of 300,000 bpd from its crude oil and petroleum product exports until the end of December.

The cuts could be extended into the first quarter of 2024 because of "seasonally weaker oil demand at the start of every year, ongoing economic growth concerns and the aim of producers and OPEC+ to support the oil market's stability and balance", said UBS strategist Giovanni Staunovo.
Oil prices rebounded after both benchmarks fell by around 6% in the week to November 3, as supply concerns driven by Middle East tensions eased.
UN agency leaders demanded a humanitarian ceasefire on Monday, a month into the war in Gaza, as health authorities in the enclave said the death toll from Israeli strikes now exceeded 10,000.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Economists say inflation figures coupled with "hawkish" commentary from the RBA suggest they will likely raise interest rates this afternoon. The official cash rate has remained steady at 4.1% since June, after the RBA increased rates 12 times since May 2022. Inflation data for the September quarter came in stronger than the central bank's forecast. ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell says the RBA will do what it can to bring inflation back within its target range. "We do think that will be a rate hike, and this is something and that comes from hawkish commentary from the Reserve Bank," she said. "So they've said look we've got these forecasts, if inflation diverges from those forecasts we do not tolerate that, they said low tolerance. "And then you know what happened? Inflation diverged from the forecast."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Hawkish commentary' from RBA points to rate rise, ANZ says

children.content: Economists say inflation figures coupled with "hawkish" commentary from the RBA suggest they will likely raise interest rates this afternoon.
The official cash rate has remained steady at 4.1% since June, after the RBA increased rates 12 times since May 2022.
Inflation data for the September quarter came in stronger than the central bank's forecast.
ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell says the RBA will do what it can to bring inflation back within its target range.
"We do think that will be a rate hike, and this is something and that comes from hawkish commentary from the Reserve Bank," she said.
"So they've said look we've got these forecasts, if inflation diverges from those forecasts we do not tolerate that, they said low tolerance.
"And then you know what happened? Inflation diverged from the forecast."
